To help, we asked active women who spend lots of time in a swimsuit to share their top picks and tips. They may spend more time in bathing suits than most, but their concerns are similar to that of most women. We all want to look ‚Ä¶

entry.title: See how the spice trade legacy continues to shape Kochi, India
entry.summary:
Kochi's inhabitants carry great pride in their spice-infused history. Gateway to the canals and lagoons of the Kerala backwaters and to the Arabian Sea, Kochi was for centuries a major hub for the spice trade. This legacy has left an indelible mark on its identity and continues to shape the multilayered city today.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). undefined undefined The backwaters can be just as colourful, with garlands of marigolds hung over the sides of boats. Representing the sun and symbolising brightness and auspiciousness, marigolds are often used during celebrations and as offerings throughout India. Kerala‚Äôs backwaters run parallel to the Arabian Sea, stretching north and south of Kochi. They‚Äôre home to plantations growing a variety of spices such as cloves, nutmeg, cardamom, cinnamon and turmeric. Fruits including bananas, coconuts and mangoes also thrive here. Life on the plantations is dictated by the rhythms of nature and the changing seasons. Published in the March 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe to¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: 15 of the best UK destinations for spring travel
entry.summary:
Tintern Abbey is a 13th-century gothic masterpiece sitting beside the River Wye in southeast Wales. From the Yorkshire moors to the Cornish seaside, these alluring spots make for a classic British holiday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Whether you‚Äôre longing to fill your lungs with sea air or are looking to spend some quiet days rambling through the countryside, these UK destinations are all perfectly suited to spring travel. From the ‚ÄòQueen of Welsh resorts‚Äô to the region that‚Äôs home to the UK‚Äôs rarest butterfly species, these are 15 of the best destinations to escape to this Easter holiday and beyond.
The West Midlands county of Staffordshire was once a powerhouse of innovation, taking 18th-century¬†Britain¬†into a ground-breaking fu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rediscover real island living
entry.summary:
White sand, blush-pink granite boulders, and verdant coastal forest define the inner islands of Seychelles. Untouched until the 18th century, Seychelles is a remarkable place of pristine natural beauty. This nation of granitic and coralline isles scattered in the Indian Ocean redefines the idea of an island escape.
There are many places that call themselves paradise, but Seychelles, near-equatorial islands strung like emeralds through the turquoise blues of the remote western Indian Ocean, surely claims the crown. A hotbed of biodiversity, these coral-fringed, jungle-clad isles were spotted by the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama in 1502, but the first Europeans to set foot here were British‚Äîrepresentatives of the British East India Company in 1609. Yet Seychelles remained unsettl‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why there's never been a better time to travel with your pets
entry.summary:
Many hotels across the globe, such as The Hoxton in Southwark, London, now cater for travellers with pets. More people are travelling with their animal than ever. Here‚Äôs what you need to know from how to fly with your dog to the latest pet-focused services.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
New statistics have highlighted the rising demand for pet-friendly travel experiences. The 2024 Annual Vacation Confidence Index by Allianz Partners USA found that over 40% of US travellers aged 34-54 years old will include their pets on their next holiday, with 24% of those over 55 doing the same.
Several travel companies in the UK have reported a rise in pet-friendly bookings over the past couple of years. Dog-friendly accommodation site Paws & Stay ‚Ä¶

entry.title: America‚Äôs original vacation hotspot is making a comeback
entry.summary:
Lake Placid and Whiteface Mountain is a famous sight of the Adirondacks. The American vacation was born in the Adirondack Mountains ‚Äî and now this remote region is experiencing a revival.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Rowing cross-handed takes some getting used to, but that‚Äôs the technique required to master an Adirondack guide boat ‚Äî the lightweight yet sturdy wooden vessel built for the rugged waterways of northern New York State. After a knuckle-bashing start with its long oars, I‚Äôm soon gliding across the glassy surface of Sagamore Lake. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre rewiring your brain right now,‚Äù says my guide, Cari Ray. ‚ÄúDoesn‚Äôt that feel good?‚Äù
The plaintive calls of a solitary loon echo across the water, but aside from this bird we‚Äôre alone on th‚Ä¶

entry.title: The harrowing history behind 'I'm Still Here'
entry.summary:
On a hot January morning in 1971, plainclothes security agents knocked on the door of the beachfront home of former Brazilian lawmaker Rubens Paiva. Hustled into his car, Paiva was sped away under armed escort and never seen again, leaving his wife and five children to pick up the pieces. This is the broad plotline of I‚Äôm Still Here, the Oscar-winning film set during Brazilian military rule. But rather than dwell on the dictators‚Äô dungeons and the all too visceral horrors of state-sponsored violence, director Walter Salles flips the narrative.
Instead, the film pivots to Paiva‚Äôs wife, then widow, Eunice, as she relentlessly presses an obtuse military junta for justice over the next five decades, even as she struggles to provide for a fractured family. It‚Äôs an intimate window on Brazil‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 luxurious hotels you can feel good about checking into
entry.summary:
Populas in Denver, Colorado, is a carbon-positive hotel, meaning that it aims to reduce more carbon than it creates. From a new purpose-driven safari in South Africa to a carbon-positive hotel in the United States, here‚Äôs how to turn your next stay into a force for good.
Travel trends come and go, but when it comes to sustainability, these hotels are all in.
‚ÄúBy choosing accommodation providers with strong sustainability practices, such as those supporting local conservation efforts or engaging in community initiatives, travelers can ensure their stays align with their personal values while positively impacting the environment and the communities they visit,‚Äù says Sally Davey, CEO of sustainable travel organization Travalyst.
Davey, who also works in collaboration with th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Deadly wildfires are making their way east
entry.summary:
Two men spray water on a raging fire as it threatens homes in Conway, South Carolina. Wildfires may be more common in the West but could deadlier in the East where they're more likely to burn through homes and businesses.  We all know wildfires have been getting worse in the drought-stricken western U.S., but experts say the growing risk on the east coast is concerning.
When we think of wildfires, we often think of western states like California where massive blazes, such as the fires that burned in and around Los Angeles earlier this year. But more than 100 fires recently burned through North and South Carolina amid dry and windy conditions.
While California and other western states face a high wildfire risk, the west is less densely populated and fires often arise in t‚Ä¶

Whether you‚Äôre facing sudden showers or chilly breezes while traveling in the spring, a reliable, lightweight jacket is an essential part of any packing list.¬†
‚ÄúLook for something you can wear year-round,‚Äù says Justin Shachter, a NASA engineer and an outdoor enthusiast based in Los Angeles, California. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll want to be protected during a 70-degree day, yet warm enough if it gets down to 45 or 50.‚Äù¬†
‚ÄúI‚Äôm looking for something water resistant.‚Ä¶

entry.title: The meaning of the cross of ashes on Ash Wednesday
entry.summary:
A woman with a cross of ashes on her forehead attends a traditional Ash Wednesday service at the Metropolitan Cathedral in San Jose, Costa Rica. The Christian holiday marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance that culminates on Easter. The holiday marks the start of a period of reflection and repentance that lasts until Easter.
Wondering why a small dusty cross anoints the foreheads of Christians once a year? They're celebrating Ash Wednesday, which for many also marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance and reflection leading up to Easter. Here's what you need to know about a holiday marked by ash crosses and fasting.
Ash Wednesday always falls on the Wednesday six and a half weeks before Easter, which Christians around the world believe is the day that ‚Ä¶

Pairwise model evaluation means comparing two models directly against each other to assess their relative performance on a specific task. The Gen AI evaluation service in Vertex AI lets you evaluate any generative model or application and benchmark the evaluation results against your own judgmentÔºå using your own evaluation criteria. entry.title: Packed with promise: Wisam‚Äôs journey back to school in Sudan
entry.summary: Wisam sits in her classroom, absorbed in her work, her fingers gripping a blue-coloured pencil, carefully sketching a flower in her notebook, one of more than 100,000 displaced students in war-torn Sudan who have returned to classes, with the support of Education Cannot Wait for the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF) efforts to distribute urgently needed school supplies to help them get back to learning.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: $2.5 billion plan to deliver aid to 11 million people in DR Congo
entry.summary: Humanitarians are calling for $2.54 billion to support operations in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), amid ongoing attacks by M23 rebels in the east and a severe funding shortfall.

entry.title: This is the worst flu season in 15 years. Here's why.
entry.summary:
Seasonal flu cases have hit¬†a 15-year high this year‚Äîfilling hospitals,¬†shutting down schools, and¬†leading to an estimated 19,000 flu-related deaths¬†so far in the¬†United States. These deaths even topped winter COVID-19-related deaths¬†for the first time since the pandemic began five years ago.
While flu cases surge, RSV, norovirus, and COVID-19 infections have also remained high, "putting a significant strain on hospitals‚Äîparticularly as patients compete for the same resources such as intensive care unit beds and healthcare personnel," says Jason Nagata, a pediatrician at University of California, San Francisco Benioff Children‚Äôs Hospital. "Hospitals are struggling to keep up with the demand, and some have been forced to set up temporary triage tents."

ÂØíÊ≠¶Á∫™Êù•ÂÆ¢Ôºå‰∏ñÁïåÈöèÊó∂Èó¥È©∂ÂêëËçíËäúÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈÉΩÂ∞ÜÊòØÁÜµÁöÑ‰ø°Âæí„ÄÇ Êü•ÁúãÁü•‰πéÂéüÊñá
‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊ∞¥Áõ¥Êé•ÈÄöËøáÈ©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Áæ§Â≤õÁöÑÁÅ´Â±±Âñ∑ÂèëÈáäÊîæÂá∫Êù•„ÄÇ ‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊ∞¥Ê∑±ÂÖ•Âú∞ÂπîÔºåÈïø‰πÖÁöÑ‰øùÁïôÂú®Âú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§Ñ„ÄÇ Âú∞ÁêÉ‰∏äÊúâ‰∏§‰∏™ÂÇ®‚ΩîÂ∫ìÔºåÁ¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊòØÂú∞ÁêÉË°®Â±ÇÁ≥ªÁªüÁöÑÂÇ®‚ΩîÂ∫ìÔºå‰ª•Êµ∑‚Ωî‰∏∫‰∏ª„ÄÇ Á¨¨‰∫å‰∏™Â∞±ÊòØÂú∞ÁêÉÂÜÖÈÉ®ÁöÑÂÇ®‚ΩîÂ∫ì‚Äî‚ÄîÂú∞ÂπîÔºåËøôÈáå‚Ωî‰ª•Âú∞ÂπîÁüøÁâ©ÁöÑÁæüÂü∫Ôºà-OHÔºâ‰∏∫‰∏ª„ÄÇ Âú®Êµ∑Ê¥ãÁöÑÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶ÈôÑËøëÔºåÂú∞ÁêÉ‰∏§Â§ßÂÇ®Ê∞¥Â∫ìÁõ∏Êé•ÔºåÊØèÊó∂ÊØèÂàªËøõË°åÁùÄÊ∞¥‰ΩìÁöÑ‰∫§Êç¢ÔºåËÄåÈ©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Êµ∑Ê≤üÂ∞±ÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶„ÄÇ Âú∞ÁêÉ‰∏äÁöÑ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶ÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜ‰∏∫‰∏§Â§ßÁ±ª: (1) Â§ßÊ¥ã‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶(2) Â§ßÈôÜ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶[1]„ÄÇ ÁéØÂ§™Âπ≥Ê¥ãÂú∞Âå∫‰∏§Á±ªÂ§ßÊ¥ã‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶Á§∫ÊÑèÂõæ Â§ßÊ¥ã‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶ÂèØ‰ª•Ëøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÂàÜ‰∏∫‰∏§ÁßçÔºå ‰∏ÄÁßçÊòØÊ¥ã - ÈôÜ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶, Â∞±ÊòØÂ§ßÊ¥ãÊùøÁâá‰øØÂÜ≤Âà∞Â§ßÈôÜ‰πã‰∏ã, ‰∫ßÁîüÂ§ßÈôÜÂºßÁÅ´Â±±Â≤©Ôºå‰æãÂ¶Ç‰∏úÂ§™Âπ≥Ê¥ãËæπÁºòÁöÑÂÆâÁ¨¨ÊñØÂ±±ËÑâ„ÄÇ Âè¶‰∏ÄÁßçÊòØÊ¥ã - Ê¥ã‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶, Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ßÊ¥ãÊùøÁâá‰øØÂÜ≤Âà∞Âè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ßÊ¥ãÊùøÁâá‰πã‰∏ã, ‰∫ßÁîüÂ§ßÊ¥ãÂºßÁÅ´Â±±‰ΩúÁî®Ôºå‰æãÂ¶ÇË•øÂ§™Âπ≥Ê¥ãËæπÁºòÁöÑÈ©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Áæ§Â≤õÔºåÊ∑±‰∏çËßÅÂ∫ïÁöÑÊµ∑Ê≤üÂíåÂ≤õÂºßÁÅ´Â±±ÈìæÁõ∏‰º¥ËÄåÁîü„ÄÇ È©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Êµ∑Ê≤üÂ∞±ÊòØÁî±Â§™Âπ≥Ê¥ãÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤Âà∞Ëè≤ÂæãÂÆæÊùøÂùó‰∏ãÈù¢ËÄå‰∫ßÁîü„ÄÇ Ë•øÂ§™Âπ≥Ê¥ãÂú∞Âå∫‰∏ªË¶ÅÊùøÂùó È©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶ È©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Êµ∑Ê≤üÁöÑ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶Â∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÂ§¥ÂêûÂô¨Â∑®ÂÖΩ„ÄÇ ‰º¥ÈöèÁùÄÂ§ßÊ¥ãÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤ÔºåÊ∂àÂ§±ÁöÑ‰∏ç‰ªÖÊúâÊ¥ãÂ£≥ÔºåËøòÊúâÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑÊ≤âÁßØÁâ©ÂíåÊµ∑Ê∞¥„ÄÇ ÂΩìÂ§ßÊ¥ãÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤Êó∂ÔºåÊùøÂùóÂèëÁîüÂºØÊõ≤Ôºå‰∫ßÁîüÂ§ßÈáèÁöÑÊñ≠Â±ÇÂíåË£ÇÈöôÔºå‰ΩøÊµ∑Ê∞¥ÂÖÖÊª°Êï¥‰∏™Ë£ÇÈöô„ÄÇ Âè¶‰∏ÄÊñπÈù¢ÔºåÊ¥ãÂ£≥ÁöÑÁâ©Ë¥®Âú®Êµ∑Ê≤üÈ´òÊ∏©È´òÂéãÁöÑÁéØÂ¢É‰∏ãÔºåÂèëÁîüÊ∞¥Âíå‰ΩúÁî®ÔºåÂΩ¢ÊàêËõáÁ∫πÂ≤©Á≠âÂõöÊ∞¥Â≤©Áü≥ÔºåÂπ∂ÈöèÊùøÂùóÁöÑ‰øØÂÜ≤ÊªëÂÖ•Âú∞Â£≥Ê∑±Â§Ñ„ÄÇ È©¨Èáå‰∫öÁ∫≥Êµ∑Ê≤ü‰øØÂÜ≤ÊâÄÊê∫Â∏¶ÁöÑÊµ∑Ê∞¥Âê´ÈáèËææ
ÔºåÊï¥‰∏™Âú∞ÁêÉ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶Ê∂àËÄóÁöÑÊµ∑Ê∞¥ÈáèËææÂà∞
Ôºå‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØÊØèÂπ¥ 30 ‰∫øÂê®[2]„ÄÇ ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶Ê∞¥Âæ™ÁéØ ‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶Ê∞¥Âæ™ÁéØ Êµ∑Ê∞¥ËøõÂÖ•Âú∞Â£≥ÂêéÔºå‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊµ∑Ê∞¥Áõ¥Êé•Âú®ÊúÄÂàùÂá†ÂÖ¨ÈáåÂÜÖÂ∞±‰ªéË£ÇÁºùÂíåÂ≠îÈöô‰∏≠ÊéíÂá∫[3]„ÄÇ Âú®Ëøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Âêë‰∏ã‰øØÂÜ≤ÂêéÔºåËææÂà∞Ê∑±Â∫¶Á∫¶‰∏∫ 20-30 km ‰∏äÂú∞ÂπîÔºåÂ∞ÅÈîÅÂú®‰øØÂÜ≤ÊùøÂùó‰∏≠ÁöÑÊ∞¥Âú®È´òÊ∏©ÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®‰∏ãÂú®‰∏äÂú∞ÂπîË¢´ÈáäÊîæÂá∫Êù•„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÈ´òÊ∏©È´òÂéãÁöÑÊ∞¥Èôç‰Ωé‰∫Ü‰∏äÂú∞ÂπîÁöÑÁÜîÂåñÊ∏©Â∫¶ÔºåÂΩ¢ÊàêÂ≤õÂºßÈìæ‰∏ãÈù¢ÁöÑÂ≤©ÊµÜ„ÄÇÈöèÁÅ´Â±±Ê¥ªÂä®Ôºå‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊ∞¥ÈáäÊîæÂà∞Â§ßÊ∞î‰∏≠ÔºåÂèÇ‰∏éÂú∞Ë°®Ê∞¥Âæ™ÁéØ„ÄÇ Ê≠§Êó∂Ôºå‰ªçÊúâ‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊµ∑Ê∞¥ÁªßÁª≠ÈöèÊùøÂùó‰øØÂÜ≤Ê∑±ÂÖ•Âà∞Âú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§ÑÔºå‰∏ÄÁõ¥ËææÂà∞Âú® 100~300km ÁöÑÂºß‰∏ãÂíåÂºßÂêéÂú∞Âπî, Èïø‰πÖÁöÑ‰øùÂ≠ò‰∫éÂú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§Ñ„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§Ôºå‰øØÂÜ≤Â∏¶ÈôÑËøëÁöÑÊ∞¥ÂêàÂíåËÑ±Ê∞¥‰ΩúÁî®ÔºåÊûÑÊàê‰∫ÜÂú∞ÁêÉÁ≥ªÁªüÊúÄ‚º§Â∞∫Â∫¶ÁöÑÊ∞¥Âæ™ÁéØ„ÄÇ ÊåâÁÖßÂú∞ÁêÉÂéÜÂè≤ÁöÑË∂Ö‚ªìÂ∞∫Â∫¶ËØ¥Êù•Ôºå‰ªäÂ§©Âú∞ÁêÉË°®Â±Ç‚ΩîÂúàÁöÑÊÄªÊ∞¥ÈáèÂ§ßÁ∫¶‰∏∫
ÔºåÊØè 100 ‰∏áÂπ¥Áî±Êµ∑Ê≤ü‰øØÂÜ≤‰∏ãÂéªÁöÑÊ∞¥Â§ßÁ∫¶ÊòØ
ÔºåÂÖ∂‰∏≠Ëøõ‚ºäÂú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§ÑÁöÑÊ∞¥Â§ßÁ∫¶Êúâ
„ÄÇ Â¶ÇÊ≠§ÁÆóÊù•ÔºåÂú∞ÁêÉË°®Â±ÇÁ≥ªÁªüÊ∞¥ÂúàÁöÑÊ∞¥ÔºåËá≥Â∞ëÊØèÈöî 16 ‰∫øÂπ¥ÊâçËÉΩÂú®Âú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§ÑÂæ™ÁéØ‚ºÄÈÅç[4]„ÄÇ Êúâ‰∫∫Êé®ÁÆóÔºåÁé∞Âú®Âú∞ÁêÉ‰∏ä‰øØÂÜ≤‰∏ãÂéªÁöÑÊµ∑Ê∞¥Â§öÔºå‰ªéÁÅ´Â±±Âõû‰∏äÊù•ÁöÑÊ∞¥Â∞ëÔºå‰∏ÄÈÉ®ÂàÜÊµ∑Ê∞¥Ê∞∏ËøúÂõöÁ¶ÅÂú®Âú∞ÂπîÊ∑±Â§Ñ„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§ÔºåËá™‰ªé 5 ‰∫øÂπ¥ÂâçÁöÑ‚ÄúÂØíÊ≠¶Á∫™‚Ω£ÂëΩ‚º§ÁàÜÂèë‚Äù‰ª•Êù•ÔºåÂú∞ÁêÉ‰∏äÁöÑÊµ∑Ê∞¥Â∑≤ÁªèÂáèÂ∞ë‰∫Ü 6%‚Äî10%„ÄÇ ÊåâÁÖßËøôÁßçÈÄüÁéáÔºåÂÖ®ÁêÉÂ§ßÊ¥ãÁöÑÊµ∑Ê∞¥ÂèØËÉΩÂ∞ÜÂú® 20 ‰∫øÂπ¥‰πãÂêéÊûØÁ´≠„ÄÇ Ê¥ãÂ£≥‰øØÂÜ≤ÈÄ†ÊàêÊµ∑Ê∞¥ËøõÂÖ•Âú∞Âπî

entry.title: How drugs like Wegovy might affect kids in the long term
entry.summary:
Fifteen-year-old Jenny Arrellin has struggled for years to lose weight through diet and exercise because of her polycystic ovary syndrome¬†(PCOS), a complex hormonal and metabolic disorder that‚Äôs associated with excess weight and insulin resistance. Knowing she was at risk of developing type 2 diabetes,¬†in March 2024 she decided to participate in a study of Wegovy, a GLP-1 receptor agonist drug similar to Ozempic.
The drug curbed her appetite considerably and changed her taste in foods‚Äî‚ÄúI stopped liking pizza and chips and now I don‚Äôt like candy at all,‚Äù she says. It also eliminated the food noise she used to get when she was bored.¬†But "the biggest change is I don't eat nearly as much as I used to," she adds.
(Can‚Äôt stop thinking about your next meal? That‚Äôs "food noise.")

entry.title: How Lake Erie became a devastating snow machine
entry.summary:
Ashtabula, OhioJim Timonere has been watching and waiting for Lake Erie to freeze over, just to catch a break.
It‚Äôs been a brutal winter for communities along the southeastern and eastern shores of Lake Erie that spans Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York.
Last Thanksgiving Day weekend, the region was paralyzed by a ‚Äúhistoric‚Äù storm that saw almost six feet of snow upend life across hundreds of miles.
‚ÄúWhen I woke up at 3 a.m. to check the snowfall I thought: ‚Äòno big deal,‚Äô‚Äù he recalls.¬†
‚ÄúTwo hours later, I looked outside, and it was: ‚ÄòOh, my god.‚Äô We got feet of snow in a matter of hours.‚Äù
Roofs of more than a dozen structures in Ashtabula collapsed, including the local high school‚Äôs, forcing hundreds of students to take online classes for a month.¬†

entry.title: If you must work on vacation, try packing a portable monitor
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
While no one should have to work on vacation, sometimes it‚Äôs unavoidable. Working on the road poses its own set of trials and tribulations, but one major complaint is the lack of monitor real estate. For some, a portable monitor may be the solution. Not only do they expand your workspace, they offer some physiological benefits too‚Äîan important consideration when you‚Äôre traveling in unfamiliar places.¬†

entry.title: Is this Portugal‚Äôs ultimate spot for stargazing?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deep in Portugal‚Äôs rural south, the region of Alentejo is dry and sun-scorched. Low hills of parched grassland roll towards the horizon, eucalyptus plants glint silver in the sun, and thousand-year-old olive trees stand sentinel over the landscape. Today, however, another colour dominates: a vast expanse of cerulean blue. This is the Alqueva Reservoir, Western Europe‚Äôs largest artificial body of water, formed in 2002. When night falls, shooting stars seem to bounce off the water and myriad constellations reflect off its glassy surface. Designated the world‚Äôs first Starlight Tourism Destination, with few towns and miles of uninterrupted countryside, the region may brim with daytime adventures, but it‚Äôs at night that Alen‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan an epic road trip from El Paso, Texas
entry.summary:
There are many extraordinary US road trips, but one of the most notable is traversing the breathtaking Southwest. Bordering Mexico and the state of New Mexico, the sun-drenched Texan city of El Paso is the ideal gateway to the sights, culture and flavours of this diverse region. Since the 16th century, El Paso has evolved from a Spanish settlement to a frontier town to a thriving border city. It now reflects a rich fusion of Spanish, Mexican and American influences, which include centuries-old missions, lively mariachi music and artisanal cowboy bootmakers. Sitting alongside the Rio Grande, El Paso‚Äôs proximity to several state and national parks makes the city a great base for an adventure-packed week-long road trip.
Start the day with a scenic drive up Transmountain Road and wa‚Ä¶

entry.title: For a new perspective on Chicago's architecture, head indoors
entry.summary:
Boat tours down the Chicago River is the most popular ‚Äî but not the only ‚Äî way to see the city's architecture. New insider tours are offering a glimpse into the usually off-limits interiors of some of the city‚Äôs most celebrated buildings.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If urban legend is to be believed, the world was forever changed on a dry, windy Chicago evening on 8 October 1871 by a cow called Daisy. She knocked over a lantern, causing one of the largest urban fires in modern history. Around 3.5sq miles of the Illinois city burned down, destroying more than 17,000 buildings and leaving a blank canvas for new architectural styles and groundbreaking engineering.
The rebuild began almost instantly and, by 1885, Chicago had enshrined i‚Ä¶

entry.title: Afraid of flying? Here are 7 tricks to manage your anxiety.
entry.summary:
Travelers typically welcome the jolt of excited adrenaline that sharpens the senses and takes our breath temporarily away‚Äîit‚Äôs the physical proof of an awe-inspiring adventure. Yet, those same reactions, far less pleasant in the form of anxiety, are also an inevitable part of travel, the other side of novelty‚Äôs biochemical coin.¬†¬†
For an increasing number of travelers, that anxiety is centered around flying. While air travel remains one of the¬†safest modes of transportation, an estimated¬†25 million adults in the United States experienced a degree of aerophobia¬†as of 2022. In the wake of tragic crashes in the first months of 2025, online searches for "fear of flying" and "flight anxiety" exponentially increased.¬†
Yet travel demand remains up, with more than¬†5 billion airline passe‚Ä¶

entry.title: What Black history has to do with the Cretaceous period
entry.summary:
As a public historian and National Geographic Explorer,¬†I‚Äôm constantly on the trail of interesting stories that connect a series of events dating back several centuries but continue to resonate into modern times. On a recent road trip through the American South, my partner, National Geographic photographer Kris Graves, and I drove through Tuskegee, Alabama, where we found a connection to a time long before human beings walked the Earth.
It‚Äôs a story of how the geology of the Cretaceous Period, between 70 and 100 Million years ago, emphatically changed the course of American history.
About 80 miles from Tuskegee, along highway 431, we approached Horseshoe Bend National Military Park. Not to be confused the "Horseshoe Bend" segment of the Colorado River in Arizona, this site, est‚Ä¶

entry.title: New report flags severity of US funding cuts to global AIDS response
entry.summary: Shuttered clinics and health workers laid off around the world reflect the widespread, negative toll the United States funding freeze is taking on the global AIDS response, according to a new situation report released on Wednesday by the UN agency charged with responding to the disease.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: UN scales up aid deliveries as regional fighting continues
entry.summary: UN humanitarians on Wednesday reported a scaling up of humanitarian aid into northwest Syria, even as hostilities continue to impact civilians and limit access in different parts of the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human Rights Council: Gaza ceasefire must hold, T√ºrk insists
entry.summary: UN human rights chief¬†Volker T√ºrk issued a¬†strong appeal on Wednesday for the fragile ceasefire in Gaza to hold, amid delays to talks between Hamas and Israel on extending the truce into the second phase.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Any peace deal must respect national sovereignty, UN envoy says
entry.summary: As the war in Sudan approaches a second year, the UN Secretary-General‚Äôs Personal Envoy for the country has emphasized the need to re-double and coordinate efforts towards a peace agreement that respects national sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity ‚Äì and end the world‚Äôs largest humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Conflict has turned parts of Sudan ‚Äòinto a hellscape,‚Äô Security Council hears
entry.summary: A senior UN aid official has called on the Security Council to ensure better protection for civilians in Sudan together with unhindered humanitarian access, as the brutal war between rival militaries approaches a second year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Greatest threat to UN Peacekeeping is divisions between nations, says UN Peace Operations Chief
entry.summary: Peacekeeping efforts by the United Nations are being challenged by growing disunity between Member States, the UN head of Peace Operations, Jean-Pierre Lacroix said in an interview with UN News, during the Conference for Women Peacekeepers in New Delhi.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Somalia faces escalating crisis amid drought, conflict and price hikes
entry.summary: The humanitarian situation in Somalia is worsening as drought, conflict and soaring food prices push millions toward extreme hunger, UN agencies warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: West Bank security situation remains alarming, warn UN aid agencies
entry.summary: Weeks of deadly Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank have turned Palestinian communities into ‚Äúbattlefields‚Äù and left 40,000 people homeless, UN humanitarians warned on Wednesday.

entry.title: Appendix A: Comparing results across Religious Landscape Studies
entry.summary: Many questions in the 2023-24 Religious Landscape Study (RLS) previously were asked in the 2007 and 2014 landscape studies. Measuring change over time on these questions is one key goal of the new RLS. But the 2023-24 survey was conducted using different methods from the 2007 and 2014 surveys, and this ‚Äúmode switch‚Äù complicates comparisons [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix A: Comparing results across Religious Landscape Studies appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9. Race and ethnicity in religious congregations
entry.summary: Americans who go to religious services tend to worship at places where most other congregants and senior leaders share their race or ethnicity. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 9. Race and ethnicity in religious congregations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 8. Religious attendance and congregational involvement
entry.summary: A third of adults attend in-person services at least monthly, while 23% virtually watch that often. And 37% are members of a house of worship. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 8. Religious attendance and congregational involvement appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Religion, fertility and child-rearing
entry.summary: Read about how adults‚Äô average number of kids vary by religious group, and how many parents pray with their kids, opt for a religious education and more. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 6. Religion, fertility and child-rearing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. Importance of religion and the Bible
entry.summary: About four-in-ten U.S. adults say religion is very important. Most Christians see the Bible as important to them. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 7. Importance of religion and the Bible appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious upbringing and childhood education
entry.summary: As a kid, most Americans say they were raised in a religion, went to religious services at least monthly, and had at least some religious education. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 5. Religious upbringing and childhood education appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Religious intermarriage
entry.summary: Most who are married say their spouse shares their religion, while 26% don‚Äôt. Read about interreligious marriages, spouses discussing religion and more. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 4. Religious intermarriage appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Identifying with a religion because of culture, ethnicity or family background
entry.summary: Identifying with a group for reasons ‚Äúaside from religion‚Äù ‚Äì such as ethnically, culturally, or because of family background ‚Äì is somewhat rare. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 3. Identifying with a religion because of culture, ethnicity or family background appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Religious switching
entry.summary: Millions of Americans have switched religions over the course of their lives, and most say their religiousness or spirituality has generally shifted too. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 2. Religious switching appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Religious identity
entry.summary: Christians‚Äô share among U.S. adults has fallen across demographic groups since 2007, but there has been overall stability in religious makeup since 2020. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 1. Religious identity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Carlo Rovelli: the physics and philosophy of time
entry.summary: What is the meaning of ‚Äònow‚Äô? An Italian physicist takes us on a journey to the edges of our understanding of time - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: ‚ÄòBorder of Tears‚Äô: Interviewing Victims of China‚Äôs Xinjiang Prison Camps
entry.summary: This award-winning investigation into Xinjiang internment camp survivors was nearly silenced. Here are some lessons learned about keeping vulnerable sources safe and telling their stories.

entry.title: Why Ramadan is the most sacred month in Islamic culture
entry.summary:
During the holy month of Ramadan, Muslims build stronger relationships with Allah through fasting, selfless actions, and praying‚Äîlike this Palestinian man praying at the Great Mosque of Gaza. The mosque, once the largest and oldest in the Gaza Strip, was destroyed by an airstrike in December 2023.

The sighting of a new crescent moon marks the start of Ramadan, a time for piety and self-reflection. Every year, Muslims around the world anticipate the sighting of the new crescent moon that signifies the official first day of Ramadan, the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and the most sacred month in Islamic culture. The start of Ramadan fluctuates each year because the lunar Islamic calendar follows the phases of the moon. It begins the day after the new crescent moon, w‚Ä¶

Guidebooks can be wonderful resources for helping travelers navigate destinations. But the best travel books can also inspire journeys. Fiction or nonfiction, there‚Äôs no shortage of books with a sense of place just waiting to spark your next adventure.¬†
As a travel journalist and lifelong book lover, I often look to books for trip ideas. When I find a new title I love, I add it to my packing list. Doing so doesn‚Äôt just encourage planning; it enhance‚Ä¶

entry.title: How a new pope is elected
entry.summary:
After Pope Benedict XVI‚Äôs resignation in 2013, it took two long weeks for the Catholic faithful to receive an answer‚Äîwho would be their next representative of God on Earth?
Crowds in Saint Peter's Square at the Vatican let out a cheer as the white smoke from burned ballots signified a successful vote among the members of the College of Cardinals.¬†It was the final act that sealed the intricate papal selection process that allegedly dates back to the time of Jesus Christ.
The drama of this sacred and mysterious ritual is depicted in the Academy Award-nominated film¬†Conclave,¬†which tells the story of what happens after the death of a fictional pope. But how much of its portrayal is true to history? Here‚Äôs a closer look at the real story behind one of the Vatican‚Äôs most mysterious a‚Ä¶

For many travelers, going on a safari is a lifelong dream. I recently lived that dream on a 14-day Namibia expedition with Wilderness Travel, where we tracked leopards and marveled at wildlife congregating at watering holes, hiked the ochre-hued Sossusvlei Dunes, and camped on ‚Äúdune beds‚Äù under a blanket of stars. I did it all with just a duffel bag and a backpack.¬†¬†
African safaris can include game drives, walking safaris, and other activities. Mo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Newfound 'Valley of the Kings' tomb is the first in 100 years
entry.summary:
For the first time in years, archaeologists have stepped inside the tomb of an ancient Egyptian pharaoh‚Äîto be greeted by hallmark hieroglyphs on the walls and traces of a faded celestial mural on the ceiling painted thousands of years ago.
Last week, Egypt‚Äôs Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities announced that a joint British and Egyptian archaeological team had uncovered the new find, which could change modern understandings of the ancient¬†kingdom at a critical time in the 15th century B.C. It also highlights how Egyptology has changed from its origins in the 19th and early 20th centuries, when the western word was ablaze with news of the treasures of this ancient civilization.
The new find is not, as some have suggested, the first royal tomb discovered in Egypt since Tutankhame‚Ä¶

entry.title: Painkillers don‚Äôt work as well for women. Here‚Äôs why.
entry.summary:
Pain is one of the oldest complaints in medical history, and for millennia, treatments have been administered with a one-size-fits-all approach. It wasn‚Äôt until recently that experts officially acknowledged one radical truth: Women experience pain differently than men, and by default, they don‚Äôt respond to treatments as well.¬†
Research shows that girls, women, and people assigned female at birth feel more severe pain than men, and are more likely to experience chronic conditions such as migraine, irritable bowel syndrome, fibromyalgia, and osteoarthritis. Yet, doctors are more likely to dismiss or ignore them, which leads to delays in treatment that exacerbate their pain.
At the same time, several studies show that over-the-counter and prescription painkillers like ibuprofen, ste‚Ä¶

entry.title: Hunting for one of the rarest butterflies‚Äînamed after her father
entry.summary:
My father once told me that the average lifespan of butterflies is seldom more than a few weeks.
Obsessed with them since he was a boy, he caught thousands during his lifetime. Using pins and tweezers, he‚Äôd straighten their wings on a wooden spreader, not a single antenna damaged. He‚Äôd then affix the insects to a foam board by piercing tiny needles through their thorax and apply chemicals to preserve their bodies and wings. He‚Äôd meticulously arrange butterflies and moths according to their species and family in display cases. With the help of a magnifying lens, he‚Äôd inscribe their Latin names on labels smaller than a sunflower seed. Encased in glass, his specimens glistened.
My father, Rustam Effendi, was a Soviet Azerbaijani lepidopterist, a preeminent authority on butterfli‚Ä¶

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/economy-work. Kim Parker, Director of Social Trends ResearchJuliana Horowitz, Senior Associate Director, Research¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Luona Lin, Research AssociateRachel Minkin, Research Associate¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Kiley Hurst, Research Analyst¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Dana Braga, Research AnalystReem Nadeem, Digital Producer¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†Peter Bell, Design DirectorJohn Carlo Mandapat, Information [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 157 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Oct. 7-13, 2024, among a sample of ATP members who indicated that they currently work either full or part [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Workers‚Äô views of AI use in the workplace
entry.summary: To explore workers‚Äô views of AI use in the workplace, we asked about their broad attitudes on how AI may be used in the future and how it will affect their job opportunities in the long run. How workers feel about AI use in the workplace About half of workers (52%) say they feel worried [‚Ä¶] The post 2. Workers‚Äô views of AI use in the workplace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Workers‚Äô experience with AI chatbots in their jobs
entry.summary: In addition to asking workers how they feel about and use AI in the workplace generally, we asked a series of questions specifically about workplace use of AI chatbots ‚Äì such as ChatGPT, Gemini or Copilot. A majority of workers (55%) rarely or never use AI chatbots at work. An additional 29% haven‚Äôt heard of [‚Ä¶] The post 3. Workers‚Äô experience with AI chatbots in their jobs appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Workers‚Äô exposure to AI
entry.summary: Overall, most American workers (63%) say they don‚Äôt use AI much or at all in their job. About one-in-six workers (16%) say at least some of their work is done with AI, including just 2% who say all or most of their work is done with AI. Some 17% of workers have not heard about [‚Ä¶] The post 1. Workers‚Äô exposure to AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: U.S. Workers Are More Worried Than Hopeful About Future AI Use in the Workplace
entry.summary: American workers have mixed feelings about how AI technologies, like ChatGPT, will affect jobs in the future. The post U.S. Workers Are More Worried Than Hopeful About Future AI Use in the Workplace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre afraid to return home‚Äô: Uprooted again, Congolese civilians face hunger and more insecurity
entry.summary: Around 700,000 people were forced to leave Goma, one of the biggest cities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) when it fell in January to rebels, known as M23. With the conflict spreading, many of them are on the move again but a return home is no guarantee of safety.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Success for polio campaign in Gaza while West Bank tensions continue
entry.summary: UN humanitarians reported on Tuesday that aid workers in Gaza supporting local health authorities have now managed to vaccinate nearly 550,000 children under 10 ‚Äì nearly all those it aimed to reach.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti: Gang violence displaces 6,000 people in one month
entry.summary: More than 6,000 people in Haiti have been forced from their homes by gang violence in almost a month, hampering aid efforts by humanitarian agencies, the United Nations warned on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Conflict in DR Congo, Europe‚Äôs ‚Äòcradle to cane‚Äô crisis, millions may go hungry in Chad
entry.summary: Ongoing fighting in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) between Rwanda-backed M23 rebels and Congolese troops has claimed more lives and forced even more families from their homes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Farmers must be at the heart of biodiversity action
entry.summary: ‚ÄúWithout the farmers, it is only political policy without implementation‚Äù ‚Äì that was the stark message delivered by the UN Food and Agriculture Organization‚Äôs Director-General on Tuesday to delegates attending the latest round of UN biodiversity talks in Rome.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO marks 20 years of its lifesaving tobacco control treaty
entry.summary: A UN treaty that addresses the global tobacco epidemic has saved millions of lives over the past two decades, the World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòPolitical courage‚Äô needed to end war in the Middle East: Top UN envoy
entry.summary: A sustainable resolution to the war in Gaza and the broader Israel-Palestine conflict relies on political courage from all sides, the top UN official for the Middle East Peace Process said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Post-war reconstruction set to cost $524 billion
entry.summary: The total cost of reconstruction and recovery in Ukraine is estimated at $524 billion (‚Ç¨506 billion) over the next decade, according to a new study published on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights chief decries substantial rise in death penalty executions
entry.summary: International efforts to eradicate the death penalty came into sharp focus at the Human Rights Council on Tuesday, where UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk decried a substantial increase in global executions in the last two years.

Ëøô‰∏çÔºåÂá†‰ΩçÁîüÁâ©Â≠¶ÂÆ∂ÂØπ‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑËÇõÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶‰∫ßÁîü‰∫ÜÂÖ¥Ë∂£ÔºåÂπ∂ËøõË°å‰∫ÜÁ†îÁ©∂„ÄÇ 2003 Âπ¥Ôºå‰∏Ä‰ΩçÂπ¥ËΩªÂ•≥Â≠êÂú®Êó•Êú¨ÂåóÈáåÂ§ßÂ≠¶ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂú∫Á†îËÆ®‰ºöÔºåÂêëËä¨ÂÖ∞Â••Âç¢Â§ßÂ≠¶ÁîüÁâ©Á≥ªÊïôÊéà Meyer-Rochow ÈóÆ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ≥‰∫é‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºö ‰ºÅÈπÖÂ∑¢Âë®ËæπÁöÑÁôΩËâ≤ÂíåÁ≤âÁ∫¢Ëâ≤Á∫øÊù°Ë£ÖÈ•∞ÊòØ‰ªÄ‰πàÔºü ÁúãÁúãÊàëÁöÑÊ∂ÇÈ∏¶Â•Ω‰∏çÂ•ΩÁúãÔºü ‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æø„ÄÇ Meyer-Rochow ÁöÑÂõûÁ≠îËÆ©Ëøô‰ΩçÂ•≥Â£´ÁæûÁ∫¢‰∫ÜËÑ∏„ÄÇ Meyer-Rochow Ëøô‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÈóÆ‰∏ÄÁ≠îÔºå‰πü‰ª§ Meyer-Rochow Êú¨‰∫∫‰πüÂØπ‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑËÇõÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶‰∫ßÁîü‰∫ÜÂÖ¥Ë∂£„ÄÇ ‰ªñÂíåÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∏§‰ΩçÂêåÈÅìÂØπ‰ºÅÈπÖËÇõÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶ËøõË°å‰∫ÜÁ†îÁ©∂„ÄÇ ÈÄöËøáÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûê[1]Ôºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂèëÁé∞ÈòøÂæ∑Âà©‰ºÅÈπÖËÇõÈó®‰∫ßÁîüÁöÑÂéãÂäõÔºåË∂ÖÂá∫‰∫Ü‰∫∫Á±ª‰ª•ÂâçÁöÑÊÉ≥Ë±°ÔºåÁõ∏ÂΩìÁöÑÊÉä‰∫∫„ÄÇ
Meyer-Rochow Á≠â‰∫∫‰∏ÄÂºÄÂßãÂÅáËÆæ‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÂê´Ê∞¥È´òÔºå‰∏∫ÁêÜÊÉ≥ÁöÑÈùûÁ≤òÊÄßÊµÅ‰Ωì„ÄÇ ÂéãÂº∫‰∏∫Ôºö
ÂΩìÁ≤™‰æø‰ªéÈõ∂Âä†ÈÄüÂà∞ 2m/s Êó∂ÔºåËÆ°ÁÆóÂæóÂà∞ÁöÑÂéãÂº∫‰∏∫ 4.6KPaÔºåËøô‰∏™ÁªìÊûúÂ§™‰ΩéÔºå‰∏éËßÇÂØüÊòéÊòæ‰∏çÁ¨¶„ÄÇ Âõ†Ê≠§,‰ªñ‰ª¨‰∏çÂæó‰∏çËÄÉËôë‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÊòØÁ≤òÊÄß‰∏∫
ÁöÑÁ≤òÊÄßÊ∂≤‰Ωì„ÄÇ ÊâÄ‰ª•ËøòÈúÄË¶ÅËÄÉËôëÂä®ÊÄÅÁ≤òÂ∫¶Ôºö
ÈÇ£‰πàËÇõÈó®ÂéãÂº∫Âàô‰∏∫Ôºö
Meyer-Rochow Á≠â‰∫∫ÂàÜÊûê‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÂú®‰∏çÂêåÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÂÖ∑Êúâ‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁ≤òÂ∫¶„ÄÇ ÊúÄÁªàËÆ°ÁÆóÂá∫Ôºö ÂΩìÊéíÂá∫‰ΩéÁ≤òÂ∫¶ÁöÑÈ´òÂê´Ê∞¥Á≤™‰æøÔºå‰ªéÈõ∂Âä†ÈÄüÂà∞ 2m/s Êó∂ÔºåÂéãÂº∫‰∏∫ 10KPaÔºåËøôÂÄíÊòØÂíå‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÑËÇõÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶Áõ∏ÂΩì[2]„ÄÇ ËÄåÂΩìÊéíÂá∫ÁöÑÁ≤™‰æøÊòØÁ±ª‰ºº‰∫éÊ©ÑÊ¶ÑÊ≤πËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÈ´òÁ≤òÁ®†Ê∂≤‰ΩìÊó∂ÔºåÂéãÂº∫ÂàôËææÂà∞ 45KPaÔºåÁõ∏ÂΩì‰∫é‰∫∫Á±ªÁöÑ 3~5 ÂÄç„ÄÇ ‰πüÂ∞±ÊòØËØ¥‰ºÅÈπÖÊéí‰æøÁöÑÂéãÂäõÔºå‰∏é‰æø‰æøÁ≤òÂ∫¶Ê≠£Áõ∏ÂÖ≥„ÄÇ
‰ºÅÈπÖÂñ∑Â∞ÑÁ≤™‰æøÊó∂ÔºåËøò‰∏ç‰ºö‰∫ßÁîüÊπçÊµÅÔºåÊµÅ‰ΩìÊïàÁéáÈùûÂ∏∏ÁöÑÈ´ò„ÄÇ Meyer-Rochow Á≠â‰∫∫Âá≠ÂÄüËøôÈ°πÁ†îÁ©∂ÔºåËé∑Âæó‰∫Ü 2005 Âπ¥ÁöÑÊêûÁ¨ëËØ∫Ë¥ùÂ∞îÂ•ñÊµÅ‰ΩìÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶Â•ñ„ÄÇ Â§öÂπ¥‰ª•ÂêéÔºå‰ºÅÈπÖËÇõÂä®ÂäõÂ≠¶Âê∏Âºï‰∫ÜÊó•Êú¨ÁöÑ‰∏§‰ΩçÂπ¥ËΩªÁ†îÁ©∂ËÄÖ„ÄÇ ‰ªñ‰ª¨Âú® 2020 Âπ¥ÔºåÂØπÈòøÂæ∑Âà©‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑËÇõÈó®Âä®ÂäõÂ≠¶ËøõË°å‰∫ÜÂÜçÊ¨°Á†îÁ©∂ÔºåÂπ∂‰ºòÈõÖÂú∞Ê∞¥‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÁØáËÆ∫Êñá[3]„ÄÇ
ËôΩÁÑ∂ÂØπ‰∫é‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑËÇõÈó®ÂéãÂäõÔºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂæóÂá∫ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâÂ§ßÂ§öÂ∞ë„ÄÇ
‰ΩÜÈÄöËøáÂØπÊ®°ÂûãËøõË°åÊîπËøõÔºåÂç¥ÂèëÁé∞‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÁöÑÂñ∑Â∞ÑË∑ùÁ¶ªÂèØ‰ª•ËææÂà∞ 1.34mÔºåÊòØÂéüÊù•Á†îÁ©∂‰∏≠ÁöÑ 0.4m Ë∑ùÁ¶ªÁöÑ 3 ÂÄçËøòÂ§ö„ÄÇ
ÂèØ‰ª•ÂèëÁé∞ÔºåËøô‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÁöÑÁ†îÁ©∂Ôºå‰∏ç‰ªÖËÄÉËôë‰∫Ü‰ºÅÈπÖÊéí‰æøÊó∂‰ºòÂåñÂñ∑Â∞ÑËßíÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âñ∑Âá∫Êõ¥ËøúË∑ùÁ¶ª„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂‰πüËÄÉËôë‰∫ÜÔºå‰ºÅÈπÖÂ∏∏Â∏∏ÂÄüÂä©È´ò‰ΩéËêΩÂ∑Æ‰ºòÂäøÔºåÂéãÂØπÊñπ‰∏ÄÁ≠πÁöÑËÄÅÂÖ≠Ë°å‰∏∫„ÄÇ ‰∏çÂæó‰∏çËØ¥ÔºåËøô‰∏§‰∏™Êó•Êú¨Â∞è‰ºôÂØπÂñ∑Â∞ÑÊ®°ÂûãÁöÑ‰ºòÂåñÔºåËøòÊòØÊå∫Âà∞‰ΩçÁöÑÔºö
‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÔºå‰∏ç‰ªÖËµ∑Âà∞‚ÄúÈóÆËøπÂØª‰ºÅ‚ÄùÁöÑÊïàÊûú„ÄÇ
ËøòÂÖ∑ÊúâÂÖ∂ÂÆÉÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈáçË¶Å‰ΩúÁî®„ÄÇ ÂñúÁà±Êä±Âõ¢ÂèñÊöñÁöÑ‰ºÅÈπÖÔºåÂÆÉ‰ª¨ÁöÑÁ≤™‰æø‰πüËµ∑Âà∞Âê∏Êî∂Êõ¥Â§öÈò≥ÂÖâÁÉ≠ÈáèÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®ÔºåÊõ¥ÊúâÂà©‰∫é‰ºÅÈπÖËøáÂÜ¨„ÄÇ ÈöèÁùÄÂõõÂ≠£Êõ¥ÊõøÔºåÂÜ∞Èõ™ËûçÂåñÔºåËøô‰∫õÁ≤™‰æøËøò‰ºöÂØπÂçóÊûÅÁîüÊÄÅÂ∏¶Êù•ÈùûÂ∏∏ÁßØÊûÅÁöÑÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇ 2014 Âπ¥ÁéØÂçóÊûÅÂ∏ù‰ºÅÈπÖÊ†ñÊÅØÂú∞Êï∞ÊçÆÂèØËßÜÂåñÂõæ Êó†ËÆ∫‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøËøòÊòØ‰ºÅÈπÖËá™Ë∫´ÔºåÈÉΩÊòØÂçóÊûÅÊµ∑Â≤∏ÔºåÁ¢≥„ÄÅÊ∞Æ„ÄÅÁ£∑‰ª•ÂèäÂÖ∂ÂÆÉÁîüÁâ©ÂøÖÈúÄÂæÆÈáèÂÖÉÁ¥†Âæ™ÁéØÁöÑÈáçË¶Å‰∏ÄÁéØ[4]ÔºåÊòØÂçóÊûÅÊµ∑Â≤∏ÁîüÊÄÅÁπÅËç£ÁöÑ‰øùÈöú„ÄÇ
Á†îÁ©∂ËÄÖ‰∏ç‰ªÖÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂàÜÊûê‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑÁîüÁêÜ„ÄÅÈ•ÆÈ£üÔºå‰ª•ÂèäÁîüÂ≠òÁéØÂ¢É„ÄÇ ËøòÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÊ∞∏ÂÜªÂ±Ç‰∏≠ÁöÑÁ≤™‰æøÔºåÁ†îÁ©∂Êï¥‰∏™ÂçóÊûÅÁöÑÂè§Ê∞îÂÄôÂíåÁîüÊÄÅÂèòËøÅ„ÄÇ‰ªéÊüêÁßçÊÑè‰πâ‰∏äÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÊ∞∏ÂÜªÂ±Ç‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÔºåËµ∑Âà∞‰∫ÜÊó∂Èó¥ËÉ∂ÂõäÁöÑ‰ΩúÁî®„ÄÇ ‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÁöÑÈ¢úËâ≤Â§öÁßçÂ§öÊ†∑Ôºö Youngflesh Ê≠£Âú®ÂçóÊûÅÁßëËÄÉËàπ‰∏äÂàÜÊûê‰ºÅÈπÖÁ≤™‰æøÁöÑÂÖâË∞±ÂíåÂåñÂ≠¶ÊÄßË¥® Ëøô‰∫õÈ¢úËâ≤‰∏ªË¶ÅÂàÜÊàêÁôΩËâ≤ÂíåÁ≤âÁ∫¢Ëâ≤„ÄÇ ‰Ω†ÁîöËá≥ÂèØ‰ª•ËØ¥Ôºå‰ªäÂ§©ÊãâÁôΩËâ≤Á≤™‰æøÔºåËøòÊòØÁ∫¢Ëâ≤Á≤™‰æø‰∏ªË¶ÅÁúã‰ºÅÈπÖÁöÑÂøÉÊÉÖ„ÄÇ Âõ†‰∏∫ÂÆÉ‰ª¨Âπ≤È•≠ÂøÉÊÉÖ‰∏∫È±ºÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂñ∑Âá∫ÁôΩËâ≤‰æø‰æøÔºõ Âπ≤È•≠ÂøÉÊÉÖ‰∏∫Á£∑ËôæÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂñ∑Âá∫Á∫¢Ëâ≤‰æø‰æø„ÄÇ Á£∑ËôæÂøÉÊÉÖÁöÑÈ≤∏Ôºå‰πü‰ºöÊéíÂá∫Á∫¢Ëâ≤‰æø‰æø

entry.summary:
Ê∫ØÊ∫™ËßÖ‰∫ëË∏™ Êü•ÁúãÁü•‰πéÂéüÊñá

entry.title: It‚Äôs possible to reverse diabetes‚Äîand even faster than you think
entry.summary:
Diabetes is a debilitating, life-threatening chronic illness that puts people at greater risk of blindness, kidney failure, and heart disease. But we‚Äôre also increasingly learning that it‚Äôs not a condition a person needs to live with forever.¬†
One in 10 people in the United States and more than 830 million¬†people worldwide have the disease‚Äî91 percent of them with type 2 diabetes; which, unlike type 1 diabetes, tends to develop in adulthood. About a¬†third of Americans also have prediabetes‚Äîthough more than 80 percent of them¬†don't know they have it.
"Type 2 diabetes is like having termites in your home in that it doesn't show¬†many symptoms at first, but can cause significant internal damage over time," says Osama Hamdy, senior staff physician at the Joslin Diabetes Center¬†in Massa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Antoni Porowski wants you to learn your ancestors‚Äô recipes
entry.summary: Chef Fabio Delledone shows Antoni Porowski and actor Justin Theroux how to make tortelli at Ristorante Belrespiro in Agazzano, Italy. As the host of No Taste Like Home, Porowski travels with celebrities to their ancestral homeland to explore their genealogy and the origins of their family‚Äôs culinary traditions. The Queer Eye star discusses his obsession with food, and helping others find their family history through food in the new travel series No Taste Like Home. Antoni Porowski believes in the importance of storytelling through culinary traditions. The child of Polish parents who immigrated to Montr√©al, he ‚Äúfelt Polish enough‚Äù until the family moved to West Virginia and he began high school. Wanting to hang out with the cool kids, he noticed how he stood out‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is what a surgical clinic looked like in ancient Rome
entry.summary:
A mosaic of Orpheus ringed by animals paves the floor of what archaeologists believe was the consulting room of the early third-century A.D. Surgeon‚Äôs House of Rimini, Italy. Discovered on accident in Rimini, Italy, this surgeon‚Äôs house and the hooks, scalpels, and mortars inside have expanded what we knew about ancient medicine.
Workers were hardly surprised when they stumbled upon ancient ruins in the Italian town of Rimini in 1989. Now a popular tourist destination along the Adriatic coast, Rimini‚Äîor Ariminum in ancient times‚Äîhad been a major Roman town for centuries, and the modern city is strewn with monuments from that period.
What the workers found that spring day, however, would lead archaeologists to something quite unique: a cache of surgical instruments that had lai‚Ä¶

entry.title: Near perfect skull of apex predator reveals its 'meat cleaving bite'
entry.summary:
A species of the Hyaenodonta family as depicted by Heinrich Harder in Wilhelm Bolsche‚Äôs Tiere der Urwelt (Animals of the Prehistoric World). A new fossil from this extinct predator gives scientists clues to how it lived and hunted. Some were the size of a dog. Others were as large as polar bears. A newly-discovered fossil of the ferocious hyaenodont is helping scientists understand a little bit more about the mysterious creatures.
Long before wolves or big cats, large hyaenodonts prowled the landscape.
Despite their name, the carnivores were not hyenas. Hyaenodonts were an ancient group of four-legged flesh-eaters that spread from ancient Europe through Africa, Asia, and North America between 56 and about 5 million years ago.
Most were small, comparable to a medium-sized‚Ä¶

entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
If you‚Äôre planning to travel outside the United States, you need a reliable travel adapter and power converter. Differences in international power grids means there are no universal standards for voltage, frequency, or plug types around the world. Depending on where you go and which devices you‚Äôre charging, you may need an adapter, a converter, or both.¬†
A travel adapter simply lets you plug into different outlets. A converter adjusts the voltage s‚Ä¶

entry.title: Winter brings more indoor air pollution
entry.summary:
Most of us associate air pollution with the outdoors‚Äîfrom car or bus exhaust in a city to industrial waste or wildfire smoke. But you may not realize the air inside your home can be even more contaminated, especially in winter. Since home is where we spend some 70 percent of our time‚Äîmore if you‚Äôre one of the 35 percent of workers who do some or all business from there‚Äîthese toxins can have an outsized impact on your health.
Outdoor pollutants are regulated by the Clean Air Act, but no comparable federal law governs what lurks inside your dwelling. Yet exposure to common winter indoor toxins can cause myriad health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, chronic inflammation, and cancer. Some research has even linked them to premature death, says Nicholas Nassik‚Ä¶

entry.title: Try this destination for cherry blossoms instead of Japan
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The end of South Korea‚Äôs long, frigid winter is announced by puffs of pink and white. Cherry blossom season is a big deal here, celebrated with local festivals and flower-themed drinks ‚Äî and it‚Äôs as beautiful as it is fleeting. Southern Jeju island sees its first blossom in mid-March, while up in the mountains of the northern mainland, buds can linger on until the end of April. The blooms usually peak a week or so after first appearing, and soon after lie in pale mounds on the ground.
It‚Äôs difficult to avoid comparisons with neighbouring Japan, over the sea. There, cherry blossom-viewing ‚Äî an experience known locally as hanami ‚Äî is more well-established. But South Korea is the more affordable of the two countries, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of the most scenic train journeys in the UK
entry.summary:
The North Yorkshire Moors Railway was first launched in the 1830s. UK rail is once again in the spotlight as the country marks the 200<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the world‚Äôs first public railway this year. Pay tribute to those early pioneers by riding the UK‚Äôs most scenic rails.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mainland Europe has been basking in a not-so-quiet rail revolution for the past few years, but now the spotlight is firmly on the UK. 2025 marks 200 years since the opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway ‚Äî the world‚Äôs first public railway ‚Äî and the much-anticipated Britannic Explorer, A Belmond Train arrives in July. As train travel across the UK takes off once more, here are eight train journeys with views you won‚Äôt want to mi‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to explore Oman's green peaks
entry.summary: High in¬†the¬†rocky mountains of Oman‚Äôs interior,¬†the¬†desert¬†blooms, beckoning travellers to experience a corner of the country that's resplendent in its rural beauty. Jabal Akhdar is around two hours' drive from Muscat and enjoys a mild microclimate thanks to an inland position and high altitude. As a result, it's home to flourishing landscapes, with fruit and rose orchards smothering slopes in fragrant and colourful blossoms. Visitors can easily immerse themselves in its spectacularly rugged landscapes on foot, with the milder weather providing ample opportunities for exploration of its villages and hiking routes. Witness the plunging depths of nearby Wadi Ghul ‚Äî nicknamed ‚Äòthe Grand Canyon of Arabia‚Äô, while ancient settlements carved into Jabal Akhdar's precipices add a surreal beauty to ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to eat and drink in Copenhagen
entry.summary: With 26 Michelin stars found across its historic streets, Copenhagen is undeniably a culinary powerhouse. The city is home to some of the world‚Äôs most innovative restaurants ‚Äî including Alchemist, a theatrical dining experience headed by Rasmus Munk, the reigning World‚Äôs Best Chef ‚Äî yet, there‚Äôs no need to break the bank on a visit here. There are plenty of affordable restaurants showcasing traditional Danish cuisine, as well as first-rate bakeries, where you‚Äôll find delights like the ‚ÄòViennese‚Äô (a pastry named after the city in which its Danish creator found inspiration). On a winter visit, join the locals on a quest to find the city‚Äôs best fastelavnsboller ‚Äî seasonal cakes that liven up bakery windows from January onwards. From street-side food vendors to rustic waterfront breweries, thi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Greenland: life at the edge of the world
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Inuit of Greenland have 80 different words for ice. Niels Davidsen is currently most familiar with sikuuvoq (sea covered by a layer of ice) because the sikuuvoq has stolen his boat. It is currently sikkuppaa (frozen into sea ice) in the harbour of Ilulissat, on the west coast of Greenland, and there it will stay for a couple more months. Come June, the thaw will rescue the vessel and its many neighbours, or else the town will decide its winter visitor has outstayed its welcome and employ an ice-breaker or dynamite to swiftly blast an ammavoq (passage in sea ice for a boat to pass through) and be done with it.
For now, though, Niels visits his little white boat in Illulissat harbour every so often to chip off th‚Ä¶

entry.title: This asteroid might not hit Earth in 2032 after all
entry.summary:
Asteroids fly by Earth on a regular basis, and most of them are of no concern whatsoever. But sometimes a space rock gets flagged as a potential threat because there is a slim chance that it may collide with Earth. A newly discovered near-Earth asteroid called 2024 YR4 is one possibly perilous object: It‚Äôs a 130 to 300-foot long rock that could impact somewhere on Earth on December 22, 2032.
To be clear, there is no need to hurriedly invest in a hardened bunker. This asteroid is certainly worth watching because it could devastate a city with a direct hit‚Äîeven on the small side of its size estimate. At one point, the rock had a 3.1 percent chance of a violent rendezvous with Earth‚Äîthe highest ever recorded. The odds have since fallen to 1.5 percent and will most likely, drop precipitou‚Ä¶

entry.title: In Catalonia, try this self-sufficient fine-dining restaurant
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the hills to the west of Barcelona, Casa Nova is a temple to the art of slow, soulful cooking. It‚Äôs the kind of place that, using only what is naturally abundant, relies on age-old methods and the particularities of a region‚Äôs terrain, climate and cultures.
In fact, the restaurant, a farmhouse in the fertile Pened√®s countryside famed for its white wines, claims to be 98% self-sufficient, with the remainder sourced from local producers. There are just seven staff who grow, cook, deliver and then explain all the food ‚Äî no waiters ‚Äî and a dining room with only six tables, Casa Nova offers an experience akin to visiting a friend‚Äôs farm ‚Äî if that friend happened to be one of the world's most innovative chefs.
An‚Ä¶

entry.title: Go on a luxury rail journey through Peruvian mountains
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Holding aloft pairs of dry coca leaves, the dancers pause, drums beating faster, before they burst into song. Over shouts of ‚ÄúHeh! Heh! Heh!‚Äù, they play melodies on a quena (an Andean flute) while passengers gather around, squinting through the smoke from offerings burning on the platform at Poroy Station. Coloured with vegetable dyes, the welcome troupe‚Äôs skirts flare as they hop from one foot to the other, setting the tone for the next four hours: a journey filled with music, colour and Indigenous Quechua culture.
I‚Äôm here to ride the luxury Hiram Bingham, run by Belmond Trains, from the district of Cusco in southeastern Peru to the town of Aguas Calientes in the foothills of the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Pic‚Ä¶

entry.title: Amtrak's Gulf Coast train line is back‚Äîhere‚Äôs what‚Äôs to expect
entry.summary:
En route to Biloxi from New Orleans, the train passes Gulfport Beach in Mississippi. Amtrak‚Äôs southern route prepares to reopen, following a 20-year hiatus after Hurricane Katrina.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Linking the Mardi Gras capital of New Orleans in Louisiana and the waterfront city of Mobile in Alabama, Amtrak‚Äôs Gulf Coast train is set to become one of the USA‚Äôs great rail routes once more when it relaunches in spring 2025. Following the southern US shoreline for most of its three-hour journey, it passes through Louisiana‚Äôs Cajun country ‚Äî known for its miles of bayous, traditional festivals and hearty gumbos (spicy Cajun chicken soup) ‚Äî and coastal Mississippi. The latter is a lesser-visited area with white-sand beaches, fresh c‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ukraine war: Amid shifting alliances, General Assembly passes resolution condemning Russia‚Äôs aggression
entry.summary: Three years to the day since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the UN General Assembly adopted two competing resolutions on resolving the conflict on Monday, one initiated by the United States and the other by Ukraine ‚Äì a sign of strategic differences within the transatlantic alliance over the way forward for peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Famine in Sudan, Gaza polio campaign continues, West Bank update, Kenyan officer killed in Haiti
entry.summary: Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres expressed deep concern on Monday following the announcement by Sudan‚Äôs Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia and affiliated groups, of a political charter proposing the establishment of a rival governing authority in RSF-controlled areas to the transitional Government.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Eastern DR Congo: Crisis deepens as crime and insecurity surges
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is worsening as M23 rebel attacks continue to drive tens of thousands from their homes and claim hundreds of lives, UN humanitarians warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nuclear weapons are ‚Äòone-way road to annihilation‚Äô warns Guterres
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres on Monday warned that the risk of nuclear conflict is rising ‚Äì as global security arrangements unravel and military spending soars ‚Äì urging governments to push for total disarmament.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Breast cancer cases projected to rise by nearly 40 per cent by 2050, WHO warns
entry.summary: Breast cancer cases are expected to increase by 38 percent globally by 2050, with annual deaths from the disease projected to rise by 68 percent, according to a new report from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a specialised branch of the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UKRAINE LIVE: Diplomatic debate intensifies as world marks three years since full-scale Russian invasion
entry.summary: February 24 marks three years since Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Thousands of civilians have been killed and injured, the economy shattered and energy infrastructure destroyed. As the General Assembly and Security Council debated how peace and security can be restored in eastern Europe, three resolutions were passed which reveal new policies and alliances that signal a major shift in the pattern of diplomacy towards the war, here in New York. UN News app users can follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World‚Äôs ‚Äòwarmongers‚Äô must end disdain for global order, UN chief insists
entry.summary: With no end to numerous protracted conflicts - not least in Ukraine, three years to the day since the full-scale Russian invasion - UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres on Monday scorned the world‚Äôs ‚Äúwarmongers‚Äù for trampling on people‚Äôs most fundamental rights.

entry.title: Using WhatsApp to Crowdsource Data on Ride Hailing Companies‚Äô Labor Lockouts
entry.summary: Bloomberg investigative data journalist Leon Yin used WhatsApp to crowdsource data from Uber and Lyft drivers in New York City about company lockouts during a local, minimum wage dispute.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: The Future of Funding Investigative Journalism: Strategies & Challenges
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, attendees will learn how to diversify revenue streams, approach funders while safeguarding editorial independence, and adapt to the evolving funding landscape. The panel brings together three top experts with deep experience in media fundraising, business strategy, and philanthropic support for journalism, ready to share their knowledge and real-world strategies.

entry.title: Ukraine: Guterres says ‚ÄòEnough is Enough‚Äô as war reaches the three-year mark
entry.summary: Monday marks three years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, in clear violation of the UN Charter and international law, and the UN Secretary-General has renewed his call for de-escalation and an end to the conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine three years on: Pain, loss, solidarity and hope for a better future
entry.summary: 24 February 2025 marks the third year of the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine, and the civilian population continues to face near daily-attacks. The UN staff living alongside them, enduring the same difficult conditions, have been a lifeline throughout the war.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New round of polio vaccinations begins in Gaza
entry.summary: The latest round of a large-scale polio vaccination campaign in Gaza targeting nearly 600,000 young children got underway on Saturday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN in Ukraine prepares for the worst, hopes for the best
entry.summary: As the full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine reaches its third year, a flurry of diplomatic activity has led to a growing expectation of a ceasefire, although the situation remains extremely fluid. Despite the uncertainty, the UN is planning how to best support the country when the fighting finally stops.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Explainer: 5 common myths about child marriage
entry.summary: Every day, almost¬†one in five young women are married off while still children, according to the UN reproductive and sexual health agency, UNFPA, which is urging countries to say ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt‚Äù to child marriage, an illegal practice that is almost universally condemned and yet remains widespread globally.
